text: Had fun giving talks on #HFpEF at the @HFSA board review course today. Made some "HFpEF connections" puzzles for the audience, in the style of @nytimes connections puzzles. See if you can figure it out! Match groups of 4 clues that are connected. https://t.co/nIK1Cxcd3e https://t.co/8OP3KQ9pl0
Today's HFpEF connections: https://t.co/urBOJbs8eO https://t.co/tSADHaiOSs
Today's #HFpEF connections: https://t.co/urBOJbsG4m https://t.co/8EHWf4uMJg

We're hiring! 2 positions: (1) senior statistical analyst, (2) lead research data analyst. Looking for mid-career, strong communication skills, experience with @STS_CTsurgery research or other large cardiovascular research projects. Cardiac surgery research is a plus. More info👇

Willing to consider fully remote work. These positions are in our @NMCardioVasc Clinical Trials Unit, which I direct. Links to the positions:

Senior Statistical Analyst: https://t.co/wxkmIUsXA9

Lead Research Data Analyst: https://t.co/bYJkbZPbtJ
DM me if questions or if you want to recommend anyone who may be interested
1/ How to use the H2FPEF score (https://t.co/0wdlig3ogV) to assist with the diagnosis of #HFpEF. https://t.co/oFNjd2idD5
8/ A low H2FPEF score in the presence of overt objective evidence of HF in a patient with LVEF ≥50% is indicative of a possible HFpEF masquerader or atypical etiology of HFpEF.

9/ Like any score, H2FPEF not perfect, so proceed to definitive testing, carefully examine echo, perform invasive hemodynamics, consider CPET if something isn't adding up when evaluating your patients.

1/ #HFpEF treatment algorithm #tweetorial. This is the algorithm I currently use to treat HFpEF based on evidence we have thus far and my anecdotal experience treating patients over the past 16 years in the @NMCardioVasc HFpEF Clinic.

7/ Step 4: Is volume overload present? If so, start diuretics, with preferential up-front use of an MRA (e.g., spironolactone) and loop diuretics as needed (but minimize loop diuretic dose once euvolemic)
8/ Step 5: Treat comorbidities… https://t.co/ZIco3unq9Z

26/ Caveats (cont’d): ARNI most effective if EF <55-60% or frequent HF hosp (congested phenotype); avoid in pts with history of angioedema, low BP, orthostatic hypotension, restrictive cardiomyopathy, pulmonary arterial hypertension, constrictive pericarditis, cardiac amyloidosis
27/ Caveats (cont’d): AF patients often have low stroke volume and inability to augment stroke volume during exertion due to LA dysfunction. Avoid excessive rate control in these patients.

1/ Grant-writing tips. This #tweetorial mainly applies to @NIH grants (particularly R01s) but some stuff may be applicable to other types of grants and funding agencies. Based on my experience writing grants for 20 yrs +lots of cringe-worthy missteps and rejections along the way!

17/ Investigator, Part 2: You want to make your investigative team shine, so the biosketches need to be clear, informative, and relevant. Include relevant letters of support, and make sure your letter writers highlight your great work and accomplishments.

18/ Investigator, Part 3: Insert a brief section in your grant on qualifications of the investigative team + why you're uniquely suited to do the proposed work. Add citations that back up your statements. Highlight prior collaborative publications (here and in your biosketches).

29/ Miscellaneous #4: Figures. Unless it's a photo, use vector format. Create your figure (eg, graph, diagram) and save as PDF format and then insert it into the document as a PDF. This will preserve the vector format so the figures are not pixelated (raster format, e.g., JPEG).

I use a Mac and make my figures in PowerPoint. Then I copy the entire figure and Edit > Paste Special… and paste it as a PDF. I then copy that PDF version of the figure and paste it into Word. See comparison below, the vector format is clean; raster format is grainy. https://t.co/2XTvCPbxMa

Reading in the echo lab today... a woman in her 70s with HTN, diabetes, hyperlipidemia presents to ER with shortness of breath. Echo below. IVC was small and collapses >50% consistent with normal RA pressure (0-5 mmHg). What's the diagnosis? https://t.co/jg7UGFIBqG

The echo shows prominent diastolic septal flattening but minimal systolic septal flattening. Normally we see this with RV volume overload, but est. RA pressure was normal. So we need to think of other mechanisms that would cause diastolic septal flattening...
Mitral E velocity was 0.5 cm/s and E/A ratio was 0.6. So the left heart was underfilled. Here is the answer... https://t.co/bMAMIbnvHj

Interested in #ATTR #amyloidosis? If you're a current US-based cardiology fellow or cardiologist please consider applying to our paid, 1-year, immersive ATTR cardiac amyloidosis fellowship (clinical + research, starts July 1, 2022). More info here: https://t.co/fzSp56OvhJ
https://t.co/6mv46x9Lod
https://t.co/4YSvPR7bN1

Diagnosis = apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Nothing changed between baseline and 3-month echo, but the 2nd echo speckle-tracking was done correctly.
https://t.co/GuOYXosK0K

#HFpEF pearl of the day: never trust just 1 piece of information on an echo or echo report. For patients with HFpEF especially, we always need to review the echos ourselves to make sure we have the correct diagnosis!
3 months later, echo was repeated. Speckle-tracking LV longitudinal strain bullseye map now look like this. What's the diagnosis? Hint: it's NOT amyloid :) https://t.co/geCOt6aV2I
By the way, here is the ECG at time of first echo... and  is unchanged 3 months later... https://t.co/LEMF9dFHxH
The case of the changing speckle-tracking LV longitudinal strain bullseye map.... what's the diagnosis? See https://t.co/LR4mZMVPUo https://t.co/jxyr4KhCg3

A woman in her late 60s with a history of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, HTN, DM2, DVT, TIA, hypothyroid, ILD, OSA, and GERD presents to ER with leg swelling. Echo shows the following. What's the diagnosis? (thx @nakhtermd for showing me this case!) https://t.co/uwKhaXn5iu

PRESERVED-HF is now published and online @NatureMedicine. RCT of #SGLT2i vs placebo in n=324 #HFpEF pts, LVEF>45%. Clearly positive trial with no heterogeneity by LVEF. +5.8 improvement in KCCQ and +20.8 meter improvement in 6MWT distance. @MkosiborodMD  https://t.co/9AjpJO1Zv0
https://t.co/6JCAkreEtH

PRESERVED-HF enrolled patients that are more like the kind of typical #HFpEF patients we see (compared to prior SGLT2i trials in patients with HF and LVEF>40%). PRESERVED-HF had more women, ⬆️diversity, more obesity, lower NTproBNP, higher LVEFs, lower KCCQ.
83-year-old man with HFpEF, NYHA class III. What does the PW Doppler tracing of the RVOT (below) show and what does it mean? https://t.co/WsRaJdkDwP

GUIDE-HF results presentation by @LindenfeldJoann at @escardio #ESCCongress... expanding #CardioMEMS to NYHA class II and patients with elevated NTproBNP without HF hospitalization... my take-home is that it is a positive trial given pre-COVID-19 impact analysis https://t.co/d4kHGIgrCB
Seems to work just as well (or better) in HF with LVEF > 40%. Interested to see how patients with HFpEF (LVEF ≥ 50%) did... https://t.co/7nlVlLL1fd
https://t.co/zT3eWaXyl2

#GUIDE-HF results stratified by HFrEF, HFmrEF, and HFpEF, per @TheLancet paper (https://t.co/j2uf4vLWbw). No heterogeneity. P(interaction) = 0.75. HFpEF (LVEF≥50%, n=492): HR 0.86 (95% CI 0.68-1.08), p=0.20. https://t.co/0J88GbIoY1
(Also, there may be an error in the paper, N's for each EF subgroup don't add up and are flipped in the main paper vs. supplementary material forest plot).

Pre-COVID analysis: Overall (N=1000), primary endpoint: HR 0.81 (95% CI 0.66-1.00), P=0.049. No heterogeneity. P(interaction) = 0.51. HFpEF (LVEF≥50%): HR 0.70 (95% CI 0.47-1.03), P=0.067. https://t.co/M5udQ68uxL

EMPEROR-Preserved results, presented by Stefan Anker @escardio #ESCCongress. Clear reduction in HF hospitalization with no heterogeneity across LVEF 40-50, 50-60, > 60 (interaction p=0.21). Amazing results for our patients, huge advance for our #HFpEF field. https://t.co/jIFxOHH108
https://t.co/X3VEiFPLaA
https://t.co/79m2Jud8Vm

Despite interaction p=0.21 by LVEF, effect seemed to attenuate at ⬆️LVEF. Await further dissection of the data, but wonder if some patients with LVEF>60% didn't have significant congestion. Will know more once we have DELIVER results and can meta-analyze results across true pEF.

Great discussion on interatrial shunt devices going on today at @CSIcongress #CSIvirtual. Lots of devices in this field, and lots more to learn about whether or not these devices can help improve symptoms and outcomes in our patients. https://t.co/9ycbyElwo6
https://t.co/82B8fEHLrM

1/ I am eagerly awaiting the EMPEROR-Preserved late-breaking clinical trial results presentation tomorrow @ESCardio #ESCCongress. Based on the press release, it looks like for the first time ever we will have a clearly positive phase 3 trial in #HFpEF. But how positive?
6/ And we have shown in the studies above that CKD and albuminuria are also associated with adverse cardiac mechanics in HFpEF. https://t.co/D8c2XBRpsl

7/ In my clinical practice of taking care of #HFpEF patients, as long as there are no contraindications, I have already incorporated use of SGLT2i as first line therapy (with MRAs) to treat volume overload, and try to minimize loop diuretics.
#HFpEF pearl of the day: Here is my latest HFpEF treatment algorithm. Modified from https://t.co/bpBCLGgWS0. Part 1/2: https://t.co/eeP6k0rtN0
Part 2/2 of the #HFpEF treatment algorithm: https://t.co/O7sMZUoTOd

#HFpEF pearl of the day: The RV cares about total afterload and not the site of pulmonary vascular dz. That’s why PA compliance (PA pulse pressure/SV) & PA effective elastance (PASP/SV) are better markers of prognosis than PVR or DPG. @RyanTedfordMD. See: https://t.co/FZR68701U3.

Though admittedly Rx of CpcPH (especially ⬆️DPG) is a challenge as described in my earlier tweets. Here is how I conceptualize the different phenotypes of PH in HFpEF, which has implications for treatment: https://t.co/6RFtJzLout
How can we improve PA compliance (central PA stiffening)? Device-based treatment to improve PA compliance may be a possibility. See: https://t.co/UXnQyNObCw
Here are some examples of normal and abnormal hepatic vein PW Doppler tracings... https://t.co/DBkKELwTQS
https://t.co/KVGfEoy1IF
https://t.co/nPtXz7IbwF
Follow-up to yesterday's #HFpEF pearl of the day: Based on the subcostal echo image of the hepatic vein shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Systolic flow reversal in the hepatic veins is equivalent to tall V waves on the CVP tracing. In this pt, bubbles only reflux into the hepatic vein during systole. When she takes a breath in, there is no diastolic reflux of bubbles, arguing against restrictive cardiomyopathy. https://t.co/nxSG8giEsb

This pt likely had a combo of severe TR + stiff RA. Occasionally we see systolic flow reversal into the hepatic veins in patients with a stiff RA or RV in the absence of severe TR (though some TR is typically present).

#HFpEF pearl of the day: hepatic vein imaging on echo is simple and can provide insight into underlying hemodynamic status and pathophysiology in HFpEF patients. I find it is helpful to be present at the bedside when imaging the hepatic vein, and I use this very simple algorithm: https://t.co/ROlZCNef2b

#HFpEF pearl of the day: LV wall stress (=pressure x radius/wall thickness) varies throughout the cardiac cycle. HFpEF pts = ⬆️ aortic stiffness ➡️ ⬆️ reflected wave. Typically LV is protected b/c wall stress peaks early in systole, but in HFpEF peaks later ➡️ ⬆️myocardial damage https://t.co/wVxbk8rFh6

Why is this important? ⬆️Ao wave reflections = risk factor for HFpEF + comorbidities (e.g., CAD) likely predispose to later shift in peak LV systolic wall stress, right when reflected wave hits the LV = ⬆️myocardial damage. Rx of Ao stiffness or comorbidities could ⬇️LV dysfxn.
See also: https://t.co/tNAAYZ9biD
https://t.co/Y9FAIqCtxo
https://t.co/XzqIs6I8QG

Answer to yesterday's case: Large unroofed coronary sinus ASD with bidirectional shunting. See yesterday's thread for images and discussion. Many great ideas/guesses were posted. The main lesson is that "normal" labs (like upper normal Hgb/Hct) in overt "HFpEF" ➡️ expand the DDx!

#HFpEF pearl fo the day: Kussmaul's sign (⬆️JVP w/inspiration) is one of the easiest physical signs to elicit (watch neck veins while listening to lungs). If present, it's a clear sign of cardiac pathology (restrictive cardiomyopathy, constriction, severe TR, RV dysfunction). https://t.co/dyr2bjS3eh

The patient in the video above had NYHA class III symptoms of dyspnea on exertion with minimal evidence of fluid overload on exam. Cardiac work-up was "normal". But looking back at the echo after the physical exam showed Kussmaul's sign revealed the following: https://t.co/zzP9ehEw9U

Although cardiac chamber measurements were "normal", it is clear from A4c view that there is significant biatrial enlargement, consistent with restrictive cardiomyopathy. This pt ended up having severe coronary microvascular dysfxn due to diabetes = likely cause of HFpEF.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Obesity is a major risk factor for HFpEF, yet we are terrible at treating it. Weight loss is as impt as diuretics in Rx'ing HFpEF successfully. I've advocated for bariatric surgery in my pts for years, but recently have tried GLP1-RAs and ketogenic diet. https://t.co/4pmtdcegJP

Case #1: 66-year-old woman with morbid obesity (BMI 46.3), HTN, OSA, HFpEF. NYHA class 3. Started ketogenic diet program with breathaylzer, and soon became consistently ketotic. 20-lb weight loss over 3 months. NYHA class 2 and on half her baseline diuretic dose. https://t.co/59l6Xm8NLR

Case #2: 68-year-old woman with obesity (BMI 39.5), DM2, HTN, HFpEF, NYHA class 2. Started GLP1-RA, which resulted in significant weight loss, BMI down to 31. NYHA class I and off of all diuretics. https://t.co/ArVFwy3nTf

1/ Potential role of endothelin and endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs) in #HFpEF (Note: would not use these drugs outside of trials in HFpEF, but there may be a subset of HFpEF pts that benefit, hopefully we'll learn from the SERENADE trial). I explain the rationale below:
11/ In #HFpEF, sitxasentan was associated with improved exercise treadmill time compared to placebo, but the drug never progressed further because of toxicities (⬆️LFTs). https://t.co/M5MF8dyB0a

12/ In SERENADE (RCT of macitentan in PH-HFpEF), there was a 4-week stabilization phase to make sure pts were not unstable or susceptible to fluid retention, then 5-week run-in period with macitentan. Pts with fluid retention during run-in were excluded prior to randomization.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Beware of “normal” labs in patients with overt HFpEF and volume overload. Just like “normal” creatinine could be indicative of hemodilution due to fluid overload, hemoglobin and hematocrit at upper limits of normal could be a clue to underlying etiology.

Here’s an example case: 73 yo man with HTN, AF, PH-HFpEF with MR, TR. Started on sildenafil by primary cardiologist for PH. When I saw him ⬆️⬆️JVP with +Kussmaul’s sign, BNP 267 pg/ml, creatinine 0.89 mg/dl, hemoglobin 15.6 g/dl, hematocrit 46.9%. Here is his ECG at the time: https://t.co/qrzofVraU8
Echo: LVEF 45%, RV dilated with RV systolic dysfunction, diastolic septal flattening, severe biatrial enlargement, 3+ TR, 3+ MR. Estimated PASP = 70 mmHg . Estimated RAP = 15 mmHg.

#HFpEF pearl fo the day: PH-HFpEF with severe RV failure is difficult to manage and is often assoc w/cardiorenal syndrome with ⬇️transrenal (MAP-CVP) pressure gradient. I use #CardioMEMS, diurese aggressively, and ⬆️BP to 130s-140s (stop anti-HTN meds, add midodrine).

⬆️⬆️PA pressure is often associated with ⬆️RV ischemia. Unlike LAD and LCx, RCA normally fills in systole and diastole. ⬆️⬆️PA systolic pressure therefore limits RCA perfusion. So need to maintain adequate systemic BP.

Maintaining adequate systemic BP also helps to "stiffen up septum" to help dysfunctional RV by providing buttress to pump against, and prevents septal bowing into LV which ⬇️LV compliance and filling. https://t.co/c0K7NW9djE

Admittedly mgmt of severe PH-HFpEF with RV failure + cardiorenal syndrome is pretty much a "data-free" zone, but I've found the mgmt strategy above to be helpful. PDE5i doesn't seem to work, and we still await SERENADE (ERA) and SOUTHPAW (oral prostacyclin) PH-HFpEF trial results
Levosimendan may be helpful in this situation based on the HELP-PH-HFpEF phase 2 RCT results, but need larger confirmatory trials. See: https://t.co/lZZtxQpTCE

Understanding signs of ⬆️ vs. normal LV and RV filling pressures on echo helped in this case. When I saw the echo, I was struck by brisk caval flow ➡️ RA + diastolic septal flattening + dilated RA/RV and normal left heart. PAPVR seemed most likely, and confirmed on cardiac CT.

Answer to yesterday's case: PAPVR causing isolated over-circulation of the right heart (RA/RV), diastolic septal flattening (indicative of RV volume overload) but with normal RA pressure, and dilated PA. https://t.co/sApqP5tnML

This pt underwent surgical correction with a baffle to connect the R upper pulmonary vein ➡️ LA via an ASD created at time of surgery. Chest pain (possibly due to coronary compression from dilated PA) and shortness of breath resolved and he continues to do well ~8 years later.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: PCWP and LVEDP shouldn't be used interchangeably. LVEDP is not the "gold standard" for PCWP. LVEDP = operating compliance of LV. PCWP = operating compliance of LA, & a more integrated measure of LA-LV coupling & the burden imposed on pulmonary circulation https://t.co/UUQ7ii6fn8

In this paper: (https://t.co/qhkkfDumkl) rheumatic valve dz, AF, and ⬆️LA diameter were predictors of PCWP "overestimation" of LVEDP. But these all are assoc. with ⬇️LA compliance which is important for what the pulmonary circulation sees in terms of the load imposed on it.

These issues also have important implications on how we classify PAH vs. PH due to left heart disease, and underscore the importance of accurate measurement of PCWP in patients with HFpEF and in the evaluation of patients with PH (instead of simply relying on the LVEDP alone).

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Once the Dx of HFpEF is made, the 1st step is looking for and Rx'ing congestion, then Rx'ing comorbidities, and then exercise/weight loss program. I use sequential nephron blockade to minimize loop diuretic dose, always try to use MRAs when possible. https://t.co/YWWMakDh4H

In the HFpEF management algorithm above, for treating HFpEF comorbidities: concomitant lung disease (e.g., COPD, ILD) is common and difficult to treat. O2 sat can ⬇️⬇️ with even mild pulmonary venous congestion b/c of poor lung reserve, so maintaining euvolemia very important.
Implantable hemodynamic monitoring can reduce respiratory hospitalizations in HF patients, as seen with #CardioMEMS. See: https://t.co/XgjDS7EEM2

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Eval of filling pressures is critical for HFpEF management. Use entire echo and integrate info for filling pressures assessment: E, E/A, decel time, pulm vein flow, LA volume, LA strain, PASP, PR end-diastolic gradient, IVC, hepatic vein, tricuspid E/e'.

⬆️E, ⬇️DT, ⬆️E/A, and D-dominant pulm vein flow (in older pts); ⬆️E/e’, ⬆️LA volume (esp. ⬆️LA min volume), ⬇️LA reservoir strain; ⬆️PASP, ⬆️PREDP gradient (in absence of PAH); ⬆️tricuspid E/e’ > 6, ⬆️size ⬇️collapsibility of IVC, hep. vein flow reversal all = ⬆️filling pressures

Also, interatrial septum bowing left to right or right to left very helpful for diagnosing imbalance in elevation of LA and RA pressures, respectively, and helpful for diagnosing underlying pathology.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: speckle-tracking strain bullseye map of the LV can help determine etiology of HFpEF. Here's an example: 58-year-old man with HTN, CKD presents with SOB, leg swelling, elevated JVP. Echo shows normal LVEF. https://t.co/0BbIJKDG3u
...and in typical tako tsubo cardiomyopathy (with the "cherry-on-the-top" pattern in reverse tako tsubo, though these are typically apparent on 2D imaging) https://t.co/tDcbdZLmD8
See also this paper of ours (with @tom_marwick and @JamesDThomasMD1): https://t.co/WITVlV13U2 https://t.co/pbfOhkByxF

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Always look at echo LVOT VTI when eval. HFpEF pts. Normal 18-22 cm at HR 60-100. ⬆️LVOT VTI: look for NASH, anemia, cirrhosis, AVMs, etc. If ⬇️LVOT VTI: infiltrative/restrictive CM, constriction, LA failure, PAH, RV failure, obstructive lung dz, MS, etc.

This is a case of severe thiamine deficiency causing high output HF (wet beriberi). The pt was on a starvation diet and only eating small amounts of pita and hummus intermittently while training for a marathon. We ruled out anemia, hyperthyroidism, and liver disease.
A treatable case of “HFpEF”! :)

Case: 70 yo woman w/paroxysmal AFib, HTN, T2DM hasn’t seen MD in a few years admitted w/acute decompensated HF. ECG with low volts. Echo: LVEF 32%, ⬆️LV wall thickness, & severely ⬇️TDI velocities (s’, e’, and a’ < 5 cm/s at the septum, nearly this low at lateral mitral annulus). https://t.co/Dm68hTiNQ0

AL labs show no evidence of a plasma cell dyscrasia. PYP scan shows heart-to-contralateral lung ratio = 1.5, qualitative grade 3 uptake. Here is the planar image (myocardial uptake corroborated on SPECT): https://t.co/HE6AfPuCj8
What would you do next?

Another case: 58 yo woman with CAD, NSTEMI, HTN, pacemaker for heart block, mixed connective tissue disease, HFpEF, evidence of restrictive CM. Worsening symptoms, right-sided HF, now w/cirrhosis. Liver bx shows sinusoidal dilation, consistent w/cardiac cause of cirrhosis. Echo: https://t.co/oumCcK5rgg
Reduced tissue velocities (particularly at the septum). https://t.co/n64IueR1DS

She had progressive worsening of symptoms so RHC was done: RA 22, RV 42/22, PA 44/25, PCWP 24, PA sat 55%, CO 2.3, CI 1.6. PYP scan showed ⬆️⬆️H/CL ratio 1.56, grade 3 uptake, confirmed on SPECT to be myocardial uptake: https://t.co/gODkJ9d8JO

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Learn the causes of false-positive Tc-PYP scan for ATTR cardiomyopathy. Always send AL amyloid lab work-up to exclude plasma cell dyscrasia, no matter what the PYP scan shows. Blood pool uptake can be ruled out with SPECT imaging. https://t.co/a0pX2U6bmw
The table above is from a great paper on this topic by @maz_hanna, @Ron_Witteles, @MarthaGrogan1, @frederickruberg, and others. https://t.co/IBjdVhgsPg

For the 2 cases I showed today: Case #1: False positive PYP scan due to recent MI. Endomyocardial bx showed no amyloid deposition, just interstitial fibrosis. Case #2: False positive PYP scan due to hydroxychloroquine toxicity. Bx: no amyloid, +intense cardiomyocyte vacuolization

This is a case of false positive PYP scan. AL amyloid work-up was negative. This pt was on hydroxychloroquine for 29 years. Endomyocardial biopsy showed intense vacuolization of cardiomyocytes, consistent with hydroxychloroquine cardiotoxicity.

Answer: endomyocardial biopsy. Recent MI was the cause of false positive PYP scan. Given very +PYP uptake, would want to definitively rule out ATTR-CM so biopsy needed. Wall motion was tip-off to exclude MI. CMR would help but would still not answer Q about ATTR-CM definitively.

DON'T GIVE THIS PATIENT TAFAMIDIS! Need to be vigilant about potential for false positive PYP scans. Perform endomyocardial bx if any doubt. PYP is a great tool, but most published studies done in pts with ⬆️pre-test prob. As we use test more widely, will learn about best uses.

Unlike TAPSE and s' velocity, RV free wall strain worsens with exercise, indicating ⬇️RV systolic function. The RV dysfunction is clear on 2D echo w/exercise, so strain not necessarily needed, but helpful to show why it's better than displacement (TAPSE) and velocity (RV s').
RV free wall strain analysis can be helpful for more subtle cases of RV dysfunction is there is a question about whether RV is augmenting appropriately with exercise.

This is a simultaneous invasive hemodynamic + echo study we did in PAH pts (IPAH and SSc-PAH pts). WIth just 15W of bike exercise, we can see that if PVR goes up, RV free wall strain gets worse. The RVFW strain in response to exercise may be a good marker of PVR change w/exercise https://t.co/wAlAo1NFeR
#HFpEF pearl of the day: In HFpEF pts with #CardioMEMS devices, bike stress echo + continuous CardioMEMS PA pressure recording can help evaluate underlying pathophysiologic abnormalities.
Systemic pulse pressure went down with exercise: https://t.co/PlWHtlMIku
At 15W exercise, PA pulse pressure went up, and RV free wall strain got worse. https://t.co/m7Digy3ALe

Based on the bike stress echo + CardioMEMS it seemed that SV fixed and inadequate HR, so CO was impaired. Blood trapped in the pulmonary circulation w/⬆️ PA pulse pressure and underfilling of LA/LV. Rx'd by ⬆️ basal HR on pacemaker, ⬆️ rate responsiveness: improved symptoms.

Ideally we could’ve done something to ⬆️pulmonary blood flow during exercise so that she could better ⬆️SV but unfortunately no options available. We continued to diurese and Rx her w/hemodynamic-guided mgmt but unfortunately she died ~1 yr later due to progressive renal failure.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Bike stress echo is very helpful in the evaluation of HFpEF. In 1 test you can diagnose HFpEF (E/e') and evaluate for CAD (WMA), health of the LA (Δ LA strain), LV contractile reserve (Δ LV strain), dynamic MR, and dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction.
TAPSE increased from 1.8 cm at rest to 2.5 cm at peak stress: https://t.co/pgidiAU0pO
RV s' velocity increased from 13 cm/s to 19 cm/s at peak stress: https://t.co/OPnIPjwDE2

#HFpEF pearl of the day. We often need to “perturb the system” in HFpEF pts to make the Dx or to understand underlying pathophys. When exercise testing is not feasible, even a simple passive leg raise (preload⬆️) maneuver can be helpful. Just use a wedge pillow under the legs.

In the example above, in the patient with non-cardiac dyspnea, both booster strain (down arrow) and conduit strain (up arrow) augmented with passive leg raise. Reservoir = booster + conduit, so reservoir strain augmented as well. None of the 3 LA strains augmented in the HFpEF pt

Change in LVOT VTI in response to passive leg raise can also be helpful. Normally LVOT VTI will go up in response to ⬆️preload. If it doesn’t, it may be a sign of a problem with the LA (sign of LA myopathy in HFpEF).

At rest, HFpEF pts often have ⬆️LV end-systolic elastance (LV systolic stiffness) (Ees) and ⬆️effective arterial elastance (arterial stiffness) (Ea). During exertion, both Ees and Ea go up. But in HFpEF, they are already elevated and can't go up further ➡️ exercise intolerance. https://t.co/wnLOKZNVEK
See: https://t.co/WgzmZjwZjm

#HFpEF pearl of the day: exercise invasive hemodynamics can help differentiate isolated post-capillary PH (IpcPH; isolated pulmonary venous HTN) vs. combined post- and pre-capillary PH (CpcPH) in HFpEF. Plot PCWP and mPAP vs. CO. In the example below, the pt. with CpcPH had COPD: https://t.co/7zXeY2cfuY

Most patients with HFpEF + CpcPH have an associated PAH risk factor (autoimmune disease, lung disease, history of PE, etc). Here is how I conceptualize the various types of PH in the setting of left heart disease: https://t.co/6ASLOMN9v0

There are 2 types of patients with CpcPH. Type 1: those with ⬆️PVR and normal diastolic pulmonary gradient (PA diastolic pressure - PCWP) < 5 mmHg. Type 2: ⬆️PVR and ⬆️DPG (> 5 mmHg). It's the Type 2 CpcPH patients who often have a PAH risk factor.

This pt had a very stiff LA, possibly due to AF ablation. There was no evidence of pulmonary vein stenosis on CT. He also had significant coronary microvascular dysfunction. But a stiff LA won’t cause big V waves with exercise by itself. Where did all the extra blood come from??

Answer to today's case: the pt had a very stiff LA, poss. due to AF ablation. But stiff LA alone cannot cause big V waves. Sympathetic activation➡️splanchnic vasoconstriction w/redistribution of volume from gut/liver➡️lungs/heart with minimal exertion + stiff LA = big V waves.
Huge improvement in symptoms, now NYHA class I-II. https://t.co/V9ALTtLIRZ
TDI shows that he has almost no atrial contractile (booster) function despite being in normal sinus rhythm. Septal a' velocity ~ 4 cm/s, lateral a' velocity ~ 3 cm/s. https://t.co/e5bEaEOOJH

#HFpEF pearl of the day: A stiff aorta can cause microvascular dysfunction, and both are often present in HFpEF. Stiff aorta = no buffer to pulsatile load = barotrauma to the microcirculation especially in high flow, low impedance organs (brain, kidney).
https://t.co/SJLjX3fW5e

#HFpEF pearl of the day: There are both "slow" and "fast" mechanisms of congestion in HFpEF patients. The "fast" mechanism is mediated by splanchnic vasoconstriction, which also may have implications for cardiorenal syndrome. https://t.co/slFuYx2v9U
See: https://t.co/5PO6UIAi0k
And: https://t.co/P2WdqJCBzv

Case: 64 yo man w/HFpEF, HTN, obesity, CAD, AF s/p ablation, NYHA 3. Invasive hemodynamics shown below. PCWP 11 at rest, ⬆️ to 32 with V waves up to 75 with 20W bike exercise. Only 1+ MR at rest/exercise. What caused the severe elevation in PCWP and V waves with minimal exercise?
By the way, at the time of his cardiac catheterization, his NTproBNP was only 98 pg/ml.

Here's an example in one of my other patients with HFpEF, NYHA class III symptoms, and BMI 39.5 kg/m2. GLP1-RA resulted in dramatic weight loss and resolution of fluid overload and HTN and symptoms. https://t.co/QpXIk8iHvd

References for pericardiotomy in HFpEF: https://t.co/zWRZPJKihF
https://t.co/BjAVRgoNhC

#HFpEF pearl of the day: A “normal” BNP or NTproBNP doesn’t rule out HFpEF. Obesity, NPPB gene polymorphisms, African ancestry, ⬆️androgenicity in women, insulin resistance, MRAs, glucocorticoids, and insufficient LV diastolic wall stress all can ⬇️BNP. #BNP_deficiency_syndrome https://t.co/zTD7pII2db
Case: 74-year-old woman with HTN, obesity (BMI 46 kg/m2) with dyspnea, leg edema, ⬆️JVP, BNP = 28 pg/ml, LVEF 60%. What is the cause of HFpEF and abnormal septal motion? https://t.co/NPgN2ELabL
https://t.co/vr1V1LSMIo
How would you treat this patient?

Another case: 61 yo woman with HTN, obesity (BMI 56 kg/m2), OSA presents with HFpEF (LVEF 60-65%). Invasive hemodynamics: RA 18, PA 56/26 (mean 36), PCWP 26, CO 6.7 L/min. A4c (rest and 25W supine bike exercise): https://t.co/2zHXKmVPhD
https://t.co/VyB3OOfFSW
Here the problem was severe chest wall adiposity with minimal pericardia/epicardial fat. https://t.co/A5T1VzTklQ

#HFpEF pearl of the day: HFpEF pts with severe obesity (BMI >35 kg/m2) can develop a distinct obese HFpEF phenotype caused by plasma volume expansion + pericardial constraint with minimal intrinsic myocardial dysfxn. Due to pericardial/epicardial fat and/or chest wall adiposity.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Evaluation of motion of the interventricular septum can be helpful to determine etiology/pathophys in HFpEF pts. Case: 58 yo man w/SOB, ascites, 2+ LE edema. EF 50%. Initially referred to hepatology for poss. liver failure. What did liver biopsy show? https://t.co/FaMIoyAJLY
What was the histologic finding on liver biopsy?

At time of transjugular liver biopsy, RA pressure = 18. Referred to me before liver biopsy result came back. ⬆️⬆️JVP w/Kussmaul's sign. Echo had been misread as abnl septal motion due to IVCD. This an obvious, clear-cut case of constriction causing diastolic septal bounce.
Mitral inflow Doppler and TDI classic for constriction. https://t.co/uf37YlLKdo
https://t.co/KujWACMh6a

When evaluating #HFpEF we can't afford to miss the Dx of constrictive pericarditis, a treatable cause of HFpEF. This pt did extremely well. and all signs of HF and fluid overload resolved post-op. Tomorrow we will continue with a more challenging case of abnormal septal motion :)

Constriction vs. restriction: remember this basic info when evaluating #HFpEF patients. Also, it's very helpful to be physically present during R/LHC or hepatic vein imaging to look at respiratory maneuvers yourself. https://t.co/7C7wLU1ofU
https://t.co/9ZizyPtBOX

If the pt is in AF or irregular rhythm consider temporary pacing above native HR during simultaneous R/LHC for consistent R-R intervals to look for concordance vs. discordance in RV and LV pressure tracings.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: For echo diagnosis of ⬆️LV filling pressures, remember the 11-13-15 rule. Septal E/e' > 11 in A-fib, > 13 with exercise, > 15 at rest (in sinus rhythm) = ⬆️LV filling pressure is likely. None of these are perfect, but good rule of thumb.
Here is a nice review on the topic: https://t.co/nvjFWTZiSx
Here is an example of septal E/e' > 13 during exercise (diastolic stress test). https://t.co/85KNAwYpP9

Diurese further. End-expiratory PCWP was 27 mmHg. She was breathing spontaneously (not on ventilator). End-expiratory RA pressure was 16 mmHg. Diuresed net negative 8L further, Cr 2.6 upon discharge from hospital. https://t.co/BNzyWhC2qv

Pts with HFpEF often have concomitant obesity and/or chronic lung disease which can cause wide swings in intrathoracic pressure so it’s important to measure invasive hemodynamics at end-expiration. And always look at the tracings yourself!

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Don’t be afraid to get an endomyocardial biopsy on your HFpEF patients to get to the bottom of the etiology of HFpEF. After all, HF is more “malignant” than most cancers. @KSharmaMD, @VirginiaSHahnMD. See: https://t.co/JlAk8gmaa5

If your center doesn’t have expertise or doesn’t do a lot of them, refer your HFpEF pt to a center that routinely does endomyocardial biopsies. Always send 1 additional sample on glutaraldehyde in case electron microscopy is needed.

Case: 63-year-old woman with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis presents with dyspnea, LE edema, fatigue. Exam JVP 12 cm, 3/6 holosystolic murmur at LSB, 1+ LE edema. LVEF 60%. TR gradient 40 mmHg, RA pressure 15 mmHg. PASP 55 mmHg.
This was her ECG at the time of presentation to my clinic: https://t.co/qf5fBKpwIY

1/ This was one of the first patients I saw in the @NMCardioVasc HFpEF Clinic when I started it in 2007 at @NorthwesternMed . This was before speckle-tracking echo was widely available and before bone scintigraphy for ATTR-CM.

10/ A good example that diastology guidelines are not perfect. Use the clinical info and 2D echo to help guide assessment of diastology. And don't be afraid to perform endomyocardial biopsy in HFpEF patients!
Additional notes: AL amyloid work-up was negative. AA amyloid unlikely because cardiac involvement is very rare though possible, another indication for endomyocardial biopsy in this patient.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: evaluation of renal fxn is challenging in HFpEF given issues with hemodilution and sarcopenia resulting in masked renal dysfxn due to ⬇️serum Cr levels. I check for ⬆️albuminuria, ⬆️intact PTH, ⬇️25-OH vit. D, ⬇️Ca2+, ⬆️PO4 to evaluate for masked CKD.
Corollary: If a symptomatic HFpEF patient comes to clinic with serum Cr ≤ 1.0 mg/dl I look for volume overload causing hemodilution.

This is also why we shouldn't be surprised if serum creatinine goes up in a HFpEF patient during diuresis (it's typically due to hemoconcentration). If in doubt, perform objective testing to determine volume status prior to stopping diuretics in HFpEF pts with rising Cr.

Case: 84 yo woman w/long-standing HFpEF admitted for volume overload. Baseline Cr 2.0 mg/dl. Diuresed 1L on hospital day #1 and Cr ⬆️ to 2.5 mg/dl. Inpatient team stopped diuresis. Given equivocal volume status -> right heart cath. PCWP reported as 10 mmHg. What would u do next? https://t.co/clhdiQOOBj

#HFpEF pearl of the day: 75% of HFpEF pts have ⬇️CFR indicative of coronary microvascular dysfxn (CMD). ⬇️CFR can be caused by coronary endothelial dysfxn, ⬆️filling pressures, myocardial fibrosis, LVH (w/insufficient coronary microvascular supply), or capillary rarefaction. https://t.co/V2UrsRoI4z

https://t.co/bgA7va0zO5
CMD is also associated with worse outcomes in HFpEF. I treat by reducing filling pressures and the usual meds for CMD and often try ranolazine to see if there is symptomatic benefit. https://t.co/N8DBAmMxnN
In PROMIS-HFpEF we used adenosine TTE with Doppler of the distal LAD. Here is an example of what LAD coronary flow looks like on TTE: https://t.co/jdAtLZ35i3
This is what is looks like on CMR (done in one of my HFpEF pts): https://t.co/Igym5OYAK5

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Every time you see a cardiac amyloid patient in clinic, always do a SEARCH to make sure you don't forget the most important aspects of optimal management. https://t.co/XsiBbrrbSi

#HFpEF pearl of the day: HFrEF is failure of the LV, HFpEF is failure of the LA. If you want to successfully manage HFpEF in your patients, you need to know at least as much about the LA as you know about the LV.
https://t.co/Zxjj44eVhq
https://t.co/DMOPvHv6xN

Answer: reduced LA reservoir strain is the closest correlate. Reduced pulmonary vein S wave can also be seen but much more variable likely given issues with adequate acquisition of the pulmonary vein signal. See the nice graph below by Brian Hoit, MD: https://t.co/LWk6OfYmJ4
And here's a summary of indices of LA dysfunction: https://t.co/wwrCaBnYWs
https://t.co/6GzN7l6VXz

#HFpEF pearl of the day: On right heart catheterization, we often think of severe MR when we see large V waves in the PCWP tracing, but in most cases (especially in HFpEF), the large V waves are due to a noncompliant LA.  Here is an example from one of my HFpEF patients (no MR): https://t.co/oP4cXcmMDV
In HFpEF patients, you can perform provocative maneuvers increase preload and bring out large V waves (indicative of poor LA reserve). Here is an example with exercise: https://t.co/sMsR7Vq5X0
Here's another example before and after 1L fluid challenge: https://t.co/LoJsfEMObW

Another thought on today's #HFpEF pearl of the day: After MitraClip, V waves in LA pressure tracing should go down due to correction of MR. If they do not, the LA may be stiff due to chronic overload/remodeling from the severe MR and the patient may not improve symptomatically.
In this situation, an interatrial shunt device may help (or the transseptal puncture performed at time of MitraClip may stay open and help unload the LA).

Final thought/question related to today's #HFpEF pearl of the day: What is the best echocardiographic correlate to big V waves on the PCWP tracing in the absence of significant MR? The answer will be related to tomorrow's #HFpEF pearl of the day :)

Answer: I increased diuretics, started carvedilol, and uptitrated it to 25 mg po bid. Confusion, dyspnea, and fluid overload resolved. LV longitudinal strain improved dramatically. Diagnosis = EtOH cardiomyopathy with LVEF higher than expected due to cirrhosis. https://t.co/QjbOGnZA0A

Can't prove the Dx, but there was no evidence of ischemia or CAD and no other obvious cause of cardiomyopathy (he refused cardiac MRI). HF was exacerbating liver failure so treating it improved mental status. I used carvedilol (non-selective BB) to avoid exacerbating portal HTN.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: If a patient with HF symptoms and normal LVEF has E/A ratio < 1 and PA systolic pressure > 50 mmHg on echo, it’s more likely PAH, not HFpEF. Low E/A ratio is due to underfilled LV due to pulmonary vascular obstruction in setting of PAH.
Here is my guide to differentiating PAH vs. CpcPH vs. HFpEF (pulmonary venous hypertension), published here: https://t.co/hgBNR5FNop https://t.co/BmfhCb67rf
And here is my checklist for the echo evaluation of PH, useful for evaluation of patients with #HFpEF: https://t.co/7RZyIPA7Rc

Example case: 62 yo F, NYHA class 3, normal LVEF. PASP 60, E/A 1.7, PCWP 22. Diuresed with improvement in symptoms. ~2 years later echo PASP higher but E/A now < 1. Now with PAH with PVR 12.4. She had a single dz that caused both HFpEF, then PAH. What's the underlying diagnosis? https://t.co/rDVfCxCFZy

Lupus and sarcoid could have also caused this. CTEPH can cause E/A < 1 and elevated PA systolic pressure but wouldn't have caused the HFpEF phenotype. I have had HFpEF patients who develop CTEPH on top of HFpEF, which leads to CpcPH.
Most CTEPH patients have E/A < 1 due to pulmonary vascular obstruction limiting flow to LA. After PTE surgery, E/A goes above 1 due to restored flow to the LA. See: https://t.co/JQvgL9bmsI

Follow-up on yesterday's #HFpEF pearl of the day. The patient had systemic sclerosis. Here are a few slides when thinking about the intersection of autoimmune disease and cardiovascular disease. https://t.co/qMYA3sKgw1
https://t.co/qpsWjML3NA

#HFpEF pearl of the day: For any given ⬆️LV filling pressure, HFpEF pts have ⬇️BNP compared to HFrEF because diastolic wall stress = pressure x radius / wall thickness. So HFpEF patients are BNP-o-penic in the face of ⬆️LV filling pressures, with ⬇️vasodilation and natriuresis.

If BNP or NTproBNP are ⬆️⬆️⬆️ in a HFpEF pt despite normal LV size and normal or ⬆️wall thickness, look for the cause: extrinsic compression of cardiomyocytes by amyloid or fibrosis; RV dilation/dysfxn; LA failure; cachexia with inability to clear BNP with NPR-C on adipocytes?

Answer: risperidone toxicity. Rapid weight gain was associated with NASH which ⬇️risperidone metabolism by liver. Citalopram also ⬇️risperidone metabolism. Both worsened weight gain. Obesity + NASH = high-output HF. ⬆️Risperidone = orthostatic hypotension.
Risperidone level checked and was ⬆️⬆️. It was weaned off with gradual weight loss and resolution of all symptoms. BNP returned to normal. Fluid overload resolved.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: HFpEF patients can have cardiac and extracardiac causes of volume overload. Abnormal LV GLS, reduced TDI velocities, and/or ⬆️⬆️ECG QRST angle (R axis – T axis) are clues to a more cardiac predominant phenotype. https://t.co/xrSKsYhaOp
https://t.co/UkfUxSgzeU
RE: ⬆️QRST angle and abnormal cardiac structure/function in HFpEF: check out this paper by one of my stellar mentees @senthil_selv: https://t.co/urnKb95oR6

#HFpEF pearl of the day: If you have a patient with definite HFpEF (clear evidence of volume overload, ⬆️LV filling pressures by cath, ⬆️⬆️E/e', ⬆️⬆️BNP, or hx of HF hospitalization) and low H2FPEF score (<5), look for atypical causes of HF with a normal LVEF. Here's an example:

49-year-old man with HTN, obesity (BMI 39), achalasia, presents with severe leg swelling on 4 diuretics, dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, elevated JVP, BNP 11 pg/ml, Cr 0.85 mg/dl, LVEF 55%, GLS -23%, normal TDI. H2FPEF score = 4 (BMI, HTN meds, E/e' = 10). What's the diagnosis? https://t.co/5UX92XREB3

Answer: giant esophagus causing compression of LA, LV, and IVC resulting in renal venous congestion + pulmonary venous congestion. Rx'd with esophagectomy with resolution of leg swelling and dyspnea. Weaned off of torsemide and metolazone, now only on ½ tab spiro+HCTZ for HTN. https://t.co/dmQHkffRhi

Here’s another case: 49 yo woman w/obesity (BMI 46), HTN, OSA on CPAP, schizoaffective with new-onset HFpEF (leg swelling, dyspnea, ⬆️JVP, BNP 226 pg/ml, LVEF 65%). Low H2FPEF score = 4 (obesity, HTN meds, E/e’ = 10). What's the diagnosis? More info....

Hospitalized 6 months ago with psychotic break, treated with uptitration of anti-psychotics, now back to baseline mental status. 60-lb weight gain over past 6 mo. Also +lightheaded/dizzy. Here's the echo: https://t.co/BT7xc3niFc

More info: normal thyroid function, normal hemoglobin, no eosinophilia. She was taking lamotragine, risperidone, and citalopram for her schizoaffective disorder. RHC: RA 13, PA 37/24, PCWP 24, CO 9.2 L/min.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Check prealbumin in your patients with HFpEF. Low prealbumin could be a sign of transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis (ATTR cardiomyopathy). Prealbumin = transthyretin. If misfolded, TTR levels will be low. TTR stabilizers (e.g., tafamidis) raise the levels.

Here is an example of how a TTR stabilizer can dramatically increase TTR (prealbumin) levels. This is from the Eidos AG10 phase 2 TTR stabilizer trial. TTR decreased or didn't change in placebo-treated pts but went up in virtually all AG10-treated pts. https://t.co/BEkuQRupio https://t.co/gfPlChLVNn

Whether the magnitude of the rise in prealbumin (TTR) levels in ATTR-CM patients treated with TTR stabilizers is associated with the magnitude of clinical benefit and reduction in adverse outcomes requires further investigation.

#HFpEF pearl of the day: Always evaluate for HFpEF in the dyspneic patient, and once you make the diagnosis the next step is figuring out etiology! Clinicians rarely try to figure out WHY the patient has HFpEF – often more than meets the eye. Here is an example...what's the dx?
https://t.co/EAzLvxu9Wm
https://t.co/nhATbH5700

Here's the answer: HCM due to a TNNT2 pathogenic genetic variant known to cause restrictive cardiomyopathy (non-obstructive HCM). CMR showed LGE in the septum which matches the LV bullseye speckle-tracking strain map. https://t.co/ACeynnFE04
Outstanding work by my stellar mentee Sandra Sanders-van Wijk (@85Svw), who did a post-doc with me in Chicago. She is an academic superstar!
#HFpEF pearl of the day: If you see the 5-5-5 sign on echo (s’, e’, and a’ tissue Doppler velocities all < 5 cm/s), think of infiltrative cardiomyopathy. https://t.co/Ccl3ttjNNq

Great day for #amyloidosis and #HFpEF: https://t.co/yRnE3CZnDr, #ESCCongress. Thanks to our 23 patients @NMCardiology @NorthwesternMed who participated in the breakthrough ATTR-ACT trial and our staff (including @dj_hammurabi) for helping make it a success!

Coronary microvascular dysfunction may be a promising therapeutic target in HFpEF. See our paper in #EurHeartJ @ESC_Journals (https://t.co/kBtPu2glco) published simultaneously today with late-breaker presentation at #ESC2018 by @lamcardio. @NMCardiology @NorthwesternMed

Check out our paper (https://t.co/D2lDTrTiGn) just published in @JAMAcardio on 1-year results from the REDUCE LAP-HF I trial of the InterAtrial Shunt Device in #HFpEF. Simultaneous publication with late-breaker presentation at #ESC2018. @NMCardiology @NorthwesternMed

REDUCE LAP-HF I shows that the IASD has 100% shunt patency at 1 year. Safe compared to sham control. HF hospitalization rates and change in NYHA class promising. Large-scale REDUCE LAP-HF II pivotal RCT ongoing and currently enrolling.

Our paper describing a human loss-of-function mutation in SERPINE1 (which encodes for PAI-1) and its association with longevity was just published in @ScienceAdvances. Congrats to @vaughalle1, @HeartDocSadiya, & the rest of our team! https://t.co/KS4EKedVoR

Our paper describing the positive results of the REDUCE LAP-HF I RCT was just published in @CircAHA. Our REDUCE LAP-HF II RCT pivotal trial is open for enrollment. https://t.co/F71KH9JBaO https://t.co/2yAAKYPy2A
What’s normal for the abnormal? A close look at NBA players’ hearts https://t.co/xwdVGVeKzA via @statnews
